questions.text: An elderly female presented with recurrent swelling of the upper eyelid. Histopathological evaluation revealed it to be a chalazion. What would be the histopathological finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lipogranuloma Focal swelling of the eyelid is a common complaint in both primary care and urgent care settings. Often, such swelling is identified as either a chalazion, appearing as a characteristically firm and painless lid nodule, or a hordeolum (stye) , which is usually painful and tender, although several other benign and malignant processes can be mistaken for these two. Chalazia (plural of chalazion) , the most common inflammatory lesions of the eyelid, are slowly enlarging eyelid nodules, formed by inflammation and obstruction of sebaceous glands of the eyelids. Chalazia can be categorized as either superficial or deep, depending on the glands that are blocked.

Highyeild:

Inflammation of a tarsal meibomian gland leads to a deep chalazion, whereas inflammation of a Zeis gland leads to a superficial chalazion .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Suppurative Granuloma - Is a granuloma caused by infectious organisms like cryptococcus, candida spores and aspergillus and characterized by the presence of abscess formation . Option: C. Foreign Body Granuloma -Foreign body Granuloma- It forms when the host immune system is unable to digest the foreign body, resulting in the accumulation of macrophages and histiocytes. Option: D. Xanthogranuloma: This is a self-limiting dermatologic disorder that is associated rarely with systemic manifestation.

Extraedge:

Chalazia can recur, and those that do should be evaluated for malignancy ; following excision of a recurrence , the content should be sent for pathologic examination .

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with cicatricial entropion of the upper and lower eyelids. On eversion of the upper eyelid, linear conjunctival scar, Arlt line is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trachoma Follicular trachoma is defined as the presence of 5 or more follicles at least 0.5 mm in diameter in the central part of the upper tarsal conjunctiva . Follicular trachoma indicates active disease. This form is most commonly found in children, with a peak prevalence in those aged 3-5 years . The prevalence rapidly decreases in school-aged children as they leave the pool of re-infection (ie, their family childcare group) . Follicles are germinal centres that primarily consist of lymphocytes and monocytes . The presence and involution of follicles at the limbus (corneoscleral border) give rise to the pathognomonic lesion of past active trachoma, Herbert pits .

Highyeild:

In the presence of secondary bacterial infection , typical symptoms of acute mucopurulent conjunctivitis develop. Congestion of the upper tarsal and forniceal conjunctiva can be seen. Conjunctival follicles appearing like boiled sago grains are commonly seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and fornix; but may also be present in the lower fornix, plica semilunaris and caruncle. Sometimes, follicles may be seen on the bulbar conjunctiva (pathognomonic of trachoma) .

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came in with tender swelling in the right lid margin pointing anteriorly through the skin, with the lash at its apex. He reported this swelling to be painful and warm. The lesion is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hordeolum The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of hordeolum . An external hordeolum (stye) is an acute staphylococcal abscess of a lash follicle and its associated gland of Zeiss that is common in children and young adults. A stye presents as a tender swelling in the lid margin pointing anteriorly through the skin, usually with a lash at its apex.

Highyeild:

Multiple lesions may be present and occasionally an abscess may involve the entire lid margin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Impetigo is a superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, typically affecting children. Involvement of the eyelids is usually associated with infection of the face . Painful erythematous macules rapidly develop into thin-walled blisters, which develop golden-yellow crusts on rupturing. There may be fever, malaise and local lymphadenopathy. Option: C. Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare but commonly very severe infection involving subcutaneous soft tissue and the skin , with associated rapidly progressive necrosis. It is usually caused by pyogenes and occasionally S. aureus. The most frequent sites of involvement are the extremities, trunk and perineum, as well as postoperative wound sites. Option: D. Erysipelas (St Anthony's fire) is an uncommon acute, potentially severe, dermal and superficial lymphatic infection usually caused by pyogenes. Diabetes, obesity and alcohol abuse are predisposing factors. An inflamed erythematous plaque develops. A well-defined raised border distinguishes erysipelas from other forms of

Extraedge:

Treatment involves topical (occasionally oral) antibiotics, hot compresses and epilation of the associated lash .

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came in with grittiness, mild photophobia and crusting and redness of the lid margins. She reported that she has been suffering from such episodes very often for the last 5 years. Symptoms are usually worse in the mornings albeit dryness of the eyes increases as the day passes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic blepharitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of chronic blepharitis Chronic blepharitis (chronic marginal blepharitis) is a common cause of ocular discomfort and irritation . The poor correlation between symptoms and signs, and the uncertain aetiology and mechanisms of the disease process all combine to make management difficult.\ Blepharitis may be subdivided into anterior and posterior forms, although there is considerable overlap and both types are often present (mixed blepharitis) . Symptoms are caused by disruption of normal ocular surface function and reduction in tear stability and are similar in all forms of blepharitis , though stinging may be more common in the posterior disease.

Highyeild:

Because of the poor correlation between the severity of symptoms and signs, it can be difficult to objectively assess the benefit of treatment. Burning, grittiness, mild photophobia and crusting and redness of the lid margins with remissions and exacerbations are characteristics.

Conjunctival follicles appearing like boiled sago grains are commonly seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and fornix; but may also be present in the lower fornix, plica semilunaris and caruncle. Sometimes, follicles may be seen on the bulbar conjunctiva (pathognomonic of trachoma) . questions.text: A 27-year-old male complains of recurrent episodes of photophobia, foreign body sensation and crusting, mainly located around the bases of the lashes. On exam, you notice the presence of mild papillary conjunctivitis, poliosis and madarosis. The exam finding is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior Blepharitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Anterior blepharitis . Hard scales and crusting are found, mainly located around the bases of the lashes and are associated with collarettes, which are cylindrical collections around lash bases as seen in the given Image. Mild papillary conjunctivitis and chronic conjunctival hyperaemia are common. Long-standing cases may develop scarring and notching of the lid margin, madarosis, trichiasis and poliosis. Associated tear film instability and dry eye syndrome are common.

Highyeild:

Blepharitis may be subdivided into anterior and posterior forms, although there is considerable overlap and both types are often present (mixed blepharitis) . Symptoms are caused by disruption of normal ocular surface function and reduction in tear stability and are similar in all forms of blepharitis , though stinging may be more common in the posterior disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Posterior blepharitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Posterior blepharitis . The Images show expressed toothpaste-like material and froth on the eyelid margin . Symptoms are caused by disruption of normal ocular surface function and reduction in tear stability and are similar in all forms of blepharitis, though stinging may be more common in the posterior disease . Option: C. In scleritis, the following findings are common: zonal necrotizing granuloma, fibrinoid necrosis, chronic inflammation, fusiform thickening, immune complex deposition with complement activation Option: D. Demodex infestation may lead to cylindrical dandruff-like scaling (collarettes ) around the base of eyelashes. The mites can be demonstrated under × 16 slit lamp magnification by first manually clearing around the base of an eyelash and then by gently rotating the lash or moving it from side to side for 5-10 seconds with fine forceps. If one or more mites (0.2-0.4 mm long) do not emerge, the lash should be gently epilated. Slide microscopy can be performed on the mites or lashes if necessary.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presented with chronic irritation, itching, mild lacrimation, glueing of cilia, and mild photophobia. On exam, you notice crusting and small ulcers which bleed on the removal of these crusts. The exam finding is shown in the image below. He reports that he has been suffering from similar episodes since childhood. Which of the options below are possible complications a. Trichiasis b. Tylosis c. Ectropion d. Epiphora e. Dry eye syndrome f. External hordeolum Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a,b,c,d,e, f The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of chronic anterior blepharitis 2 degrees to staphylococcal infection. It is a common cause of ocular discomfort and irritation . The disorder usually starts in childhood and may continue throughout life. Symptoms include chronic irritation, itching, mild lacrimation, glueing of cilia, and mild photophobia. The symptoms are characteristically worse in the morning . Remissions and exacerbations in symptoms are quite common.

Highyeild:

Signs, as seen in the given image are as below: Yellow crusts are seen at the root of cilia which glue them together. Small ulcers , which bleed easily, are seen on removing the crusts. Red, thickened lid margins are seen with dilated blood vessels (rosettes) .

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Complications and sequelae of long-standing bacterial blepharitis include all of the given options. Option: A. Lash abnormalities such as madarosis (sparseness or absence of cilia), trichiasis (misdirected cilia), and poliosis (greying of lashes) are frequently seen as complications of long-standing bacterial blepharitis. Option: B. Tylosis, i.e., thickening and scarring of the lid margin is frequently seen as a complication of long-standing bacterial blepharitis. Option C: Ectropion is frequently seen as a complication of long-standing bacterial blepharitis Option: D. Eversion of punctum leading to epiphora. Eczema of the skin and ectropion may develop due to prolonged watering. Option: E. Tear film instability and dry eye may result as complications of long-standing bacterial blepharitis Option: F. Recurrent styes (external hordeola) are common complications of long-standing bacterial blepharitis.

The Image shows the conjunctival view of Chalazion with the clamp in place. Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Skin chafing secondary to tear overflow, especially at the lateral canthus, can cause a similar clinical picture and may also predispose to infection. Option: D. Symptoms of posterior blepharitis are caused by disruption of normal ocular surface function and reduction in tear stability in a 10-year-old in all forms of blepharitis, though stinging may be more common in the posterior disease. Because of the poor correlation between the severity of symptoms and signs, it can be difficult to objectively assess the benefit of treatment. Excessive and abnormal meibomian gland secretion , manifesting as capping of meibomian gland orifices with oil globules Pouting, recession, or plugging of meibomian gland orifices Hyperaemia and telangiectasis of the posterior lid margin . Pressure on the lid margin results in the expression of meibomian fluid that may be turbid or toothpaste-like. In severe cases, the secretions become so inspissated that expression is impossible. Lid transillumination may show gland loss and cystic dilatation of meibomian ducts. The tear film is oily and foamy and often unstable, and froth may accumulate on the lid margins or inner canthi .

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with no past ocular history presents with complaints of bilateral itching, burning, foreign body sensation, and crusting over the eyelids in the morning. Although she has experienced these symptoms intermittently over the last 2 years, her symptoms have recently become worse. She denies taking any ocular medications. Her symptoms are unrelated to any systemic illness Including allergy, rosacea or flu-like symptoms. Her visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes without correction and her intraocular pressure is normal. Slit-lamp examination reveals mild erythema of the eyelid margin associated with scaling and the formation of crusting around the base of the eyelashes. Evidence of trichiasis, madarosis. Poliosis and ulceration of the eyelid are also seen. There is mild conjunctival hyperemia associated with the mild papillary reaction of the inferior tarsal conjunctiva. The tear lake in both eyes is diminished. Rose bengal dye examination of the cornea was remarkable for inferior, superficial punctate epithelial erosions. A Schirmer test was performed and revealed mild aqueous tear deficiency in both eyes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcal blepharitis There are multiple classifications of blepharitis . Marginal blepharitis is most commonly classified according to etiology. This includes blepharitis from staphylococcal colonization Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis), seborrhea, meibomian gland dysfunction or a combination of any of the above. This patient has the characteristics of staphylococcal blepharitis . Staphylococcal blepharitis has more potential to demonstrate structural damage. There may be evidence of poliosis, madarosis, and lid ulceration. Examination of the cornea may also reveal inferior punctate epithelial erosions, infiltrates, neovascularization, thinning, and phlyctenules.

Highyeild:

Staphylococcal blepharitis may lead to several forms of keratitis Including marginal infiltrates and phlyctenules . Marginal infiltrates are sterile grey-white infiltrates along the peripheral cornea at the 2-, 4-, 8-, and 10-o'clock positions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Seborrheic blepharitis is characterized by oily, greasy deposits of the anterior eyelid usually associated with seborrheic dermatitis. There may be mild conjunctival infection and inferior punctate epithelial erosions. Option: B. In cases of severe unilateral or asymmetric diastase resistance to therapy , it is always important to consider the possibility of an underlying malignancy. Rarely, sebaceous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma may masquerade as blepharitis. The presence of a nodular mass, extensive fibrosis or ulceration, and localized dermal crusting should lead to a carefu l re-evaluation of the diagnosis . However, our patient had a history, exam and course typical of blepharitis. Option: D. Patients with Meibomian gland dysfunction (posterior blepharitis) have pouting or metaplastic meibomian gland orifices, prominent vasculature crossing the mucocutaneous junction and foamy or turbid meibomian secretions. Eventual atrophy of the meibomian glands, and rosacea. There may be mild to moderate conjunctival infection, the papillary reaction of the tarsal conjunctiva, and inferior punctate epithelial erosions with occasional scarring and neovascularization.

Extraedge:

Phlyctenules are focal, triangular, elevated inflammatory nodules on the limbus, conjunctiva or cornea.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was referred to the ophthalmology department after the mandatory health checkup for his job interview. The patient reported the presence of a hard, painless swelling in the right lid, increasing very gradually in size and without inflammatory symptoms. On lid eversion, the conjunctiva is grey and the nodule has become smaller over months, but the complete spontaneous resolution has not occurred. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tarsal cyst The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Chalazion , also known as a tarsal cyst' or meibomian cyst' . This is not a cyst but a chronic inflammatory granuloma of a meibomian gland . Chalazia are often multiple, occurring in crops, and are more common among adults than in children. The glandular tissue is replaced by granulations containing giant cells, plasma cells, histiocytes and polymorphonuclear leukocytes probably as a result of chronic irritation. Retention of meibomian secretions could lead to such a reaction. The patient often notices a hard, painless swelling in either lid, increasing very gradually in size and without inflammatory symptoms. The smaller chalazion is difficult to see but is readily appreciated by passing the finger over the skin. If the lid is everted, the conjunctiva is red or purple over the nodule , in later stages is often grey, or rarely, if the infection has occurred, yellow (hordeolum internum).

Highyeild:

The grey appearance is due to alteration in the granulation tissue , which becomes converted into a jelly-like mass.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Staphylococcal blepharitis has more potential to demonstrate structural damage. There may be evidence of poliosis, madarosis, and lid ulceration. Examination of the cornea may also reveal inferior punctate epithelial erosions, infiltrates, neovascularization, thinning, and phlyctenules. Staphylococcal blepharitis may lead to several forms of keratitis Including marginal infiltrates and phlyctenules. Marginal infiltrates are sterile grey-white infiltrates along the peripheral cornea at the 2-, 4-, 8-, and 10-o'clock positions. Option: C. Hordeolum internum is a suppurative inflammation of a meibomian gland and may be due to a secondary infection of a chalazion. It is less common but the inflammatory symptoms are more violent than in an external stye because the gland is larger and embedded in dense fibrous tissue. The pus appears as a yellow spot shining through the conjunctiva when the lid is everted. It may burst through the duct or the conjunctiva , rarely through the skin. Option: D. Hordeolum externum or stye is a suppurative inflammation of a Zeis gland. In the early stages, the gland becomes swollen, hard and painful, and usually, the whole edge of the lid is oedematous. An abscess forms which generally points near the base of one of the cilia. The pain is considerable until the pus is removed. Styes often occur in crops or may alternate with boils on the neck or acne. It is commonest in young adults but may occur at any age, especially in debilitated persons.

Extraedge:

Chalazia become smaller over months , but complete spontaneous resolution rarely occurs. The contents may be extruded through the conjunctiva, in the grey-white fungating mass of granulation tissue that often sprouts through the opening, causing the conjunctival discharge and irritation to continue .

questions.text: A number of bacteria are found commonly in the environment. Which organism is not a usual commensal found on the lids and lashes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Haemophilus influenzae A number of bacteria are found commonly in the environment. These can be recovered from the eyelashes, and most of the time, they do not cause ocular disease. Corynebacterium species, Staph epidermidis, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Streptococcus viridans are frequently found. Gram-negative organisms are not usually found on the ocular surface.

Highyeild:

Pathogenic bacteria include Haemophilus influenzae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Streptococcus pneumoniae, S. aureus, Bacillus subtilis, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - All other bacterias are commensal and not pathogenic.

Extraedge:

All other bacterias are commensal and not pathogenic.

questions.text: Sauce and cheese chorioretinitis is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CMV retinitis Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis is an acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)-related opportunistic infection that can lead to blindness. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is an important ocular AIDS-associated illness. It is a full-thickness retinal infection that can lead to necrosis and retinal breaks and detachments It is a viral retinitis that can also be seen in patients who are immunosuppressed for other reasons aside from AIDS. Risk factors include HIV, CD4 count less than 50 , or severe systemic immunosuppression. On examination- Yellow-white retinal lesions often start in the periphery and follow the vasculature centripetally. However, it can start in the posterior segment. The classic findings are retinal haemorrhages with a whitish, granular appearance to the retina. Each lesion has the most activity in the borders. Vitreous signs of inflammation may be minimal as most patients are severely immunosuppressed.

Highyeild:

Very early CMV may resemble cotton wool spots, but with lesions larger than 750 µm, CMV must be considered. Three typical patterns have been described: a granular pattern, a fulminant/hemorrhagic appearance, or "frosted branch" angiitis.

Extraedge:

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs in approximately one-third of patients and the presence of concurrent keratic precipitates in a stellate fashion can also suggest CMV uveitis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a lesion in her left upper eyelid, as shown in the image below. Biopsy reveals malignant change. She also has a past history of removal of chalazion two times in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sebaceous cell carcinoma Sebaceous carcinoma is a rare, highly malignant, and potentially lethal tumour of the skin, which most commonly occurs in the eyelid. The neoplasm arises from sebaceous glands , such as those of the meibomian glands in the tarsus, the Zeis glands of the eyelashes, the caruncle, and the skin of the eyebrow. Th e lesion occurs more often in the upper eyelid , most likely due to the presence of a greater number of meibomian glands (~50 glands in upper eyelids, ~25 in lower). Sebaceous carcinoma can also occur in other body areas in 25% of cases including other areas of the head and neck and other areas of skin with hair, even genitalia

Highyeild:

Muir-Torre Syndrome (MTS) is an important consideration when a patient is diagnosed with sebaceous carcinoma . MTS is an autosomal dominant condition of sebaceous tumours associated with gastrointestinal, endometrial, and urologic tumours (without any predisposing factors).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Basal cell carcinoma BCC is the most common human malignancy and typically affects older individuals. The most important risk factors are fair skin, inability to tan and chronic exposure to sunlight. Ninety per cent of cases occur in the head and neck and about 10 per cent of these involve the eyelid. BCC is by far the most common malignant eyelid tumour , accounting for 90 per cent of all cases. It most frequently arises from the lower eyelid, followed in relative frequency by the medial canthus, upper eyelid and lateral canthus. The Image shows a lesion that is centrally ulcerated with a pearly raised rolled edge s and dilated and irregular blood vessels (telangiectasis) over its lateral margins With time it may erode a large portion of the eyelid. Option: C. Sebaceous gland carcinoma (SGC) is a very rare , slowly growing tumour that most frequently affects the elderly, with a predisposition for females. It usually arises from the meibomian glands, although on occasion it may arise from the glands of Zeis or elsewhere. The pagetoid spread refers to the extension of a tumour within the epithelium and is not uncommon. Option: D. Malignant Melanoma:

Extraedge:

The sebaceous tumours included in this syndrome are sebaceous adenoma, basal cell epithelioma with sebaceous differentiation, and sebaceous carcinoma.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further, the evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenovirus This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pharyngoconjunctival fever, a classic manifestation of a specific viral infection. Adenovirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure and the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms.

Highyeild:

Conjunctivitis and febrile pharyngitis occurring simultaneously in a patient who has spent time in close proximity to other individuals (e.g., summer camp) are highly suspicious for adenovirus infection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Human herpes virus 4 , better known as Epstein-Barr virus , is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus and the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis . The pharyngitis seen in this patient could be attributed to mono. However, individuals with mono would not be expected to present with conjunctivitis or preauricular lymphadenopathy , but rather, with hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy. Option: B. Parvovirus is a nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA virus and the causative organism of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). The fifth disease most commonly manifests with mild, cold-like symptoms, similar to this patient's presentation, after which a characteristic rash on the cheeks develops (slapped-cheek rash) . The lack of rash in this patient, taken together with the simultaneous appearance of both pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, makes another diagnosis more likely. Option: D. Picornaviridae comprises a heterogeneous group of viruses that are associated with a wide variety of diseases ranging from the common cold (rhinovirus) to viral meningitis (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus). However, Picornaviridae is a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses , whereas this patient has a DNA virus. Moreover, the Picornaviridae are not specifically linked to pharyngoconjunctivitis .

Extraedge:

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs in approximately one-third of patients and the presence of concurrent keratic precipitates in a stellate fashion can also suggest CMV uveitis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fatigue, cough, and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He appears emaciated. A chest x-ray shows a calcified nodule in the left lower lobe and left hilar lymphadenopathy. The physician initiates therapy for the condition and informs him that he will have to return for monthly ophthalmologic examination for the next 2 months. These examinations are most likely to evaluate the patient for an adverse effect of a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired production of hemozoin from heme

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired synthesis of cell wall polysaccharides

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired activity of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase

questions.correct_answer: C. Impaired synthesis of cell wall polysaccharides
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Impaired synthesis of cell wall polysaccharides This patient presents with features that suggest primary pulmonary tuberculosis (e.g., fatigue, cough, weight loss, Ghon complex on chest x-ray) . The first-line therapy for tuberculosis is a multidrug regimen consisting of rifampin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. Because optic neuropathy is an adverse effect that affects approximately 5% of patients taking ethambutol, monthly examination of visual acuity and colour vision is recommended. The mechanism of action of ethambutol is the inhibition of arabinosyltransferase, which subsequently inhibits the synthesis of arabinogalactan, an important mycobacterial cell wall polysaccharide.

Highyeild:

Polysaccharides on the outer surface of bacteri a are the principal antigens in most pathogenic bacteria, including M. tuberculosis. By inhibiting arabinosyltransferase, the bacterial cell wall becomes more permeable. A common side effect of ethambutol is reversible optic neuropathy with red-green colour blindness.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Impaired synthesis of mycolic acids is the mechanism of action of isoniazid. Isoniazid is part of the multidrug regimen used to treat tuberculosis but it is not commonly associated with optic neuropathy. A well-known adverse effect of isoniazid is peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B6 deficiency. Option: B. Impaired production of hemozoin from heme is the mechanism of action of chloroquine. A potential adverse effect of chloroquine is optic neuropathy. However, chloroquine is not part of the multidrug regimen used to treat tuberculosis. Option: D. Impaired activity of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase is the mechanism of action of rifampin. Rifampin is part of the multidrug regimen used to treat tuberculosis but it is not associated with optic neuropathy.

Extraedge:

Adverse effects of treatment with rifampin include hepatotoxicity and orange discolouration of body fluids. Furthermore, rifampin induces CYP450 activity, leading to interaction with various other drugs (e.g., clarithromycin).

questions.text: A 77-year-old man comes to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of a painful rash over his forehead, tip of the nose and left eye. He has had a fever, malaise for the past 5 days. Physical examination reveals a vesicular rash on the periorbital region and lid margins. The left eye is red, with chemosis of the conjunctiva. Microdendritic ulcer is seen on the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus It is caused by varicella zoster virus (VZV) . It remains dormant in the sensory ganglion of the trigeminal nerve. Usually in elderly people , with depressed cellular immunity, it reactivates and travels down along the branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and produces cutaneous and ocular lesions. Involvement of the tip of the nose is associated with eye involvement (Hutchinson's rule).

Highyeild:

Vesicular rash in the distribution of the cutaneous branch of ophthalmic division points towards herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Herpes simplex keratitis It is usually seen in children . The rash involves the lips, nose, eyes (HSV I) or genitals (HSV II). The rash doesn't follow the characteristic distribution (strict limitation to one side of the midline) of VZV. It presents with pain, photophobia, lacrimation and blepharospasm. Option: B. Bacterial keratitis Bacterial keratitis is usually seen in contact lens wearers, or following trauma, or chronic steroid use. It presents with red eye, conjunctival and circumcorneal congestion and hazy cornea with or without ulcer or hypopyon. Option: C. Trigeminal neuralgia The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia is made clinically based on history. It is characterized by a stabbing or shock-like pain over the distribution of the maxillary or mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve. It does not cause a rash.

questions.text: A 44 years old male comes to Eye OPD with a complaint of visual disturbance. He has a history of unprotected intercourse 20 years ago. He is also suffering from a chronic illness. On examination, the light reflex is absent in the eyes while the accommodation reflex is preserved. After further investigations, a diagnosis of Neurosyphilis is made. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The lesion is present in the ciliary ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: The size of the pupil is bilaterally equal

options.label: C
options.text: It is also known as Adie’s tonic pupil

questions.correct_answer: B. The size of the pupil is bilaterally equal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The size of the pupil is bilaterally equal The above scenario describes an Argyll Robertson pupil which is seen in Neurosyphilis . Argyll Robertson pupil is caused due to lesion in Pre tectal nucleus which causes loss of light reflex bilaterally. The pupils are of the same size. Accommodation reflex is preserved which involves the Lateral geniculate body in its pathway instead of the pretectal nucleus. Other abnormal pupillary reflexes:

Highyeild:

ADIE'S TONIC PUPIL: There is a unilateral lesion of the ciliary ganglion. Both light reflex and accommodation reflex are absent on affected size and are present on normal size. Anisocoria present. Denervation hypersensitivity is present . ( Constricts even with 0.1% pilocarpine) RELATIVE AFFERENT PUPILLARY DEFECT(RAPD): Also known as Marcus Gunn’s pupil . The earliest manifestation of Optic nerve disease. Tested by swinging flashlight test.

Extraedge:

HUTCHINSON PUPIL: Temporary constriction of the pupil due to meningeal irritation of 3rd nerve followed by permanent dilatation due to 3rd nerve palsy.
